head.title: From Where I Sit, the Commute Is Fine

hedline.hl1: From Where I Sit, the Commute Is Fine

abstract.p: Letterfrom Mary Elizabeth Anderson says unlike some New York residents in May 24 article, she does not mind her commute

block.p: Re ''In New York, a Long Way From Here to Here'' (front page, May 24), about the fact that New Yorkers spend more time getting to work than those anywhere else in the state as well as those who commute from New Jersey and Connecticut and most of the rest of the country:

Re ''In New York, a Long Way From Here to Here'' (front page, May 24), about the fact that New Yorkers spend more time getting to work than those anywhere else in the state as well as those who commute from New Jersey and Connecticut and most of the rest of the country:

My trip from Queens to Lower Manhattan may take me an hour and 10 minutes each way, but I get to spend nearly two and a half hours a day reading, or writing letters, or balancing my checkbook, or any of a number of other activities. I bet that most who commute by car can't do that.
Plus, I am happy to think that my commute does not significantly rely on fossil-fuel imports or contribute heavily to air pollution.
MARY ELIZABETH ANDERSON Kew Gardens Hills, Queens May 24, 2002
